Trial_Title: Participatory Evaluation of Aging with Rapamycin for Longevity (PEARL)
Intervention: Low-dose rapamycin (1 mg or 5 mg weekly) vs. placebo for 12 months
Primary_Endpoint: Epigenetic age (GrimAge, DunedinPACE); immune function parameters
Secondary_Endpoints: Metabolic markers; body composition; bone density; cardiovascular markers; cognitive function; safety
Key_Findings: No results available yet. One of the first rigorous RCTs testing rapamycin specifically for aging biomarkers in healthy adults.
Publication_Reference: Study design only. Results pending.

Trial_Title: Targeting Aging with Metformin (TAME)
Sponsor: American Federation for Aging Research (AFAR); PI: Nir Barzilai
Intervention: Metformin extended-release 1500 mg/day vs. placebo
Condition_Indication: Composite aging endpoints (cardiovascular event, cancer, dementia, death)
Primary_Endpoint: Time to first occurrence of composite: cardiovascular event (MI, stroke, HF, revascularization), cancer, dementia/MCI, or all-cause death
Secondary_Endpoints: Individual disease incidence; functional decline (gait speed, grip strength); epigenetic age acceleration (GrimAge, DunedinPACE); inflammatory markers (IL-6, CRP, TNF-alpha); hospitalization rate
Key_Findings: No primary results yet. FDA agreed aging can be a treatable indication. MILES pilot showed metformin reverses age-related gene expression in muscle/adipose.
Publication_Reference: Barzilai N et al. Cell Metab. 2016;23(6):1060-1065. DOI: 10.1016/j.cmet.2016.05.011; Justice JN et al. GeroScience. 2018;40(5-6):419-436.

Trial_Title: Senolytic Therapy to Modulate Progression of Alzheimer's Disease (SToMP-AD)
Sponsor: Wake Forest University / Mayo Clinic; PI: Miranda Orr
Intervention: Dasatinib 100 mg + Quercetin 1000 mg, 3 consecutive days every 2 weeks for 12 weeks (6 cycles)
Target_Population: Adults aged 65+ with early-stage Alzheimer's disease
Primary_Endpoint: Safety/tolerability; CSF senescence-associated biomarkers (p16INK4a, SASP factors); brain MRI volumetrics
Secondary_Endpoints: Cognitive assessments (ADAS-Cog, MMSE); CSF amyloid/tau; blood inflammatory markers
Key_Findings: Interim safety data: acceptable tolerability profile; no serious adverse events. Efficacy results pending.
Publication_Reference: Gonzales MM et al. Alzheimers Dement (N Y). 2021;7(1):e12170. (study design paper)

Trial_Title: Senolytic Therapy for Osteoporosis (D+Q)
Intervention: Dasatinib + Quercetin intermittent dosing
Primary_Endpoint: Bone mineral density changes; bone resorption markers
Secondary_Endpoints: Senescence markers in bone biopsies; SASP factors; physical function; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Based on preclinical data showing D+Q reduced bone loss in aged mice.
Publication_Reference: Farr JN et al. Nat Med. 2017;23(9):1072-1079.

Trial_Title: STAMINA: Senolytic Agents for Diabetic Kidney Disease (D+Q Pilot)
Intervention: Dasatinib 100 mg + Quercetin 1000 mg, 3 consecutive days (single cycle)
Condition_Indication: Diabetic kidney disease / senescent cell burden
Primary_Endpoint: Adipose tissue senescent cell markers (SA-beta-gal+ cells, p16INK4a, p21)
Secondary_Endpoints: Circulating SASP factors (IL-6, MMP-9, MMP-12); skin biopsy senescent markers; renal function
Key_Findings: First human senolytic proof-of-concept. D+Q significantly reduced adipose tissue SA-beta-gal+ cells, p16INK4a, and p21. Reduced circulating SASP factors. No serious adverse events.
Publication_Reference: Hickson LJ et al. EBioMedicine. 2019;47:446-456. DOI: 10.1016/j.ebiom.2019.08.069

Trial_Title: Senolytics in Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF D+Q Trial)
Intervention: Dasatinib 100 mg + Quercetin 1250 mg, intermittent dosing (3 days on, weeks off)
Primary_Endpoint: Safety/tolerability; SASP markers in blood and sputum; pulmonary function (FVC, DLCO)
Secondary_Endpoints: 6-minute walk distance; patient-reported outcomes; senescent cell markers in skin biopsies
Key_Findings: Earlier open-label pilot (Justice et al. 2019) showed D+Q was feasible in IPF; improved 6-minute walk, some pulmonary metrics, and physical function. Phase 2 data pending.
Publication_Reference: Justice JN et al. EBioMedicine. 2019;40:554-563. DOI: 10.1016/j.ebiom.2018.12.052

Trial_Title: Alleviation by Fisetin of Frailty Inflammation and Related Measures in Older Adults (TROFFi/AFFINITY)
Intervention: Fisetin 20 mg/kg/day for 2 consecutive days, repeated monthly for ~2 months
Primary_Endpoint: Change in circulating IL-6 and other SASP markers at 1 month
Secondary_Endpoints: Frailty index (Fried criteria); physical function (gait speed, grip strength); other inflammatory markers; T-cell senescence markers
Key_Findings: Preliminary reports indicate fisetin was well-tolerated. Primary efficacy endpoints (SASP marker reduction) showed mixed results -- some markers improved, others did not reach statistical significance.
Publication_Reference: Study design published in clinical trial registration. Full results not yet published as of early 2025.

Trial_Title: STOP-Sepsis: Fisetin to Prevent Severe COVID-19 Complications
Intervention: Fisetin 20 mg/kg/day for 2 consecutive days in hospitalized COVID-19 patients
Primary_Endpoint: Clinical severity progression (WHO ordinal scale)
Secondary_Endpoints: ICU admission; mortality; inflammatory markers (CRP, IL-6, ferritin); senescence markers
Key_Findings: Mixed results. Primary endpoint not clearly met. Some trends toward reduced inflammatory markers. Rationale was that COVID-19 induces a senescence-associated cytokine storm.
Publication_Reference: Results not fully published in peer review as of early 2025.

Trial_Title: Fisetin Pilot Study in Healthy Volunteers
Intervention: Fisetin supplementation in healthy volunteers
Primary_Endpoint: Safety and tolerability; pharmacokinetics; senescence biomarkers
Secondary_Endpoints: Blood NAD+ metabolites; inflammatory markers; frailty measures
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Evaluating fisetin safety and biomarker effects in healthy population.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: Fisetin for Healthy Aging
Intervention: Fisetin oral supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Senescence-associated biomarkers; epigenetic age changes
Secondary_Endpoints: Physical function; cognitive measures; inflammatory markers; immune cell profiling
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Designed to evaluate fisetin effects on aging biomarkers in healthy older adults.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: Fisetin for Vascular Function
Intervention: Fisetin supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Endothelial function (flow-mediated dilation); arterial stiffness
Secondary_Endpoints: Blood pressure; inflammatory markers; senescence biomarkers; oxidative stress markers
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Testing fisetin effects on vascular aging markers.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: ASPIRE (BEHOLD): UBX1325 (Foselutoclax) for Diabetic Macular Edema
Intervention: UBX1325 (foselutoclax) single intravitreal injection vs. sham injection
Target_Population: Adults with center-involved diabetic macular edema
Primary_Endpoint: Change in best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) at week 24
Secondary_Endpoints: Central subfield thickness (OCT); durability of effect; safety; senescent cell biomarkers
Key_Findings: DID NOT MEET primary endpoint. UBX1325 did not achieve statistically significant BCVA improvement vs. sham at 24 weeks. Some secondary endpoints showed trends. Well-tolerated.
Publication_Reference: Unity Biotechnology press release October 2023. Peer-reviewed publication pending.

Trial_Title: EVERLAST: Everolimus for Age-Related Functional Decline
Intervention: Everolimus low-dose regimen
Primary_Endpoint: Immune function parameters; vaccine response; functional assessments
Secondary_Endpoints: Inflammatory markers; epigenetic age; physical performance; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Building on Mannick et al. landmark everolimus immune aging results.
Publication_Reference: Based on Mannick JB et al. Sci Transl Med. 2014;6(268):268ra179.

Trial_Title: Sirolimus for Age-Related Functional Decline
Intervention: Sirolimus (rapamycin) low-dose weekly
Target_Population: Older adults aged 60+ with early functional decline
Primary_Endpoint: Physical function measures (gait speed, grip strength); frailty index
Secondary_Endpoints: Epigenetic age; immune markers; metabolic parameters; body composition; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Testing rapamycin for age-related functional decline in older adults.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: Nicotinamide Riboside for Mild Cognitive Impairment (NR MCI Trial)
Intervention: Nicotinamide riboside (NR) supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Cognitive function (MoCA, ADAS-Cog); brain NAD+ levels (MRS)
Secondary_Endpoints: Blood NAD+ metabolites; inflammatory markers; brain MRI volumetrics; safety
Key_Findings: NR supplementation increased blood NAD+ levels and showed trends toward improved cognitive measures. Safety profile favorable.

Trial_Title: Nicotinamide Riboside for Long-COVID
Intervention: Nicotinamide riboside (NR) supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Fatigue scores; functional capacity; NAD+ levels
Secondary_Endpoints: Inflammatory markers; exercise tolerance; quality of life; cognitive function; safety
Key_Findings: NR supplementation showed improvements in fatigue and functional capacity in Long-COVID patients. Published in Lancet 2025.
Publication_Reference: Lancet. 2025. (NR Long-COVID trial)

Trial_Title: NADage: Nicotinamide Riboside for Aging Biomarkers
Intervention: Nicotinamide riboside (NR) supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Epigenetic age changes (GrimAge, DunedinPACE); blood NAD+ levels
Secondary_Endpoints: Inflammatory markers; metabolic parameters; physical function; cognitive assessments; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Designed to evaluate NR effects on aging biomarkers in healthy older population.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: NMN Supplementation Trial
Intervention: Nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) oral supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Blood NAD+ levels; metabolic parameters
Secondary_Endpoints: Insulin sensitivity; body composition; physical function; epigenetic age; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Testing NMN effects on aging and metabolic endpoints.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: NMN for Insulin Sensitivity in Prediabetic Women (GeroScience NMN Trial)
Sponsor: Washington University School of Medicine; PI: Samuel Klein, Jun Yoshino
Intervention: NMN 250 mg/day orally vs. placebo for 10 weeks
Primary_Endpoint: Muscle insulin sensitivity (hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp)
Secondary_Endpoints: Blood NAD+ metabolites; body weight; blood pressure; lipids; muscle gene expression; adipose tissue function
Key_Findings: NMN increased blood NAD+ metabolites. Improved muscle insulin sensitivity by ~25% (gold-standard clamp measurement). Improved muscle insulin signaling. No change in body weight, blood pressure, or lipids.
Publication_Reference: Yoshino M et al. Science. 2021;372(6547):1224-1229. DOI: 10.1126/science.abe9985

Trial_Title: ABLE Trial: Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) for Biological Age - Singapore
Sponsor: Rejuvant / Panacea Biotech / Buck Institute collaboration
Intervention: Calcium alpha-ketoglutarate (CaAKG) 1000 mg/day for 7 months
Primary_Endpoint: Biological age (TruAge DNA methylation clock by TruDiagnostic)
Secondary_Endpoints: Blood biomarkers; self-reported health metrics
Key_Findings: Average biological age reduction of ~8 years (TruAge clock) after 7 months of CaAKG supplementation. Female participants showed greater biological age reversal. Limitations: small sample size, single-arm design, no placebo control.
Publication_Reference: Demidenko O et al. Aging (Albany NY). 2021;13(7):9711-9728. DOI: 10.18632/aging.202913

Trial_Title: Alpha-Ketoglutarate (AKG) Supplementation Trial
Intervention: Alpha-ketoglutarate supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Epigenetic age changes; metabolic parameters
Secondary_Endpoints: Inflammatory markers; body composition; physical function; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Testing AKG effects on aging and metabolic endpoints.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: Calcium Alpha-Ketoglutarate (Ca-AKG) for Healthy Aging
Intervention: Calcium alpha-ketoglutarate (Ca-AKG) supplementation
Primary_Endpoint: Biological age (epigenetic clocks); blood biomarkers
Secondary_Endpoints: Physical function; metabolic markers; inflammatory profiles; cognitive assessments; safety
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Placebo-controlled trial testing Ca-AKG effects on biological aging.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: POLYCAD: Spermidine for Coronary Artery Disease (Cardiovascular Health)
Intervention: Spermidine-rich wheat germ extract (~5-6 mg/day spermidine) vs. placebo for 3-6 months
Condition_Indication: Coronary artery disease; diastolic dysfunction (HFpEF spectrum)
Primary_Endpoint: Cardiac diastolic function (E/e ratio, echocardiography)
Secondary_Endpoints: Autophagy markers (LC3, p62); inflammatory markers; exercise capacity; biomarkers of aging
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Based on Eisenberg et al. 2016 preclinical data showing spermidine improved cardiac function and extended lifespan in mice.

Trial_Title: MitoImmune: Urolithin A for Mitochondrial and Immune Function in Older Adults
Intervention: Urolithin A (Mitopure) 1000 mg daily vs. placebo for 4 months
Target_Population: Older adults aged 65-90 with declining muscle function
Primary_Endpoint: 6-minute walk distance; muscle endurance (time to fatigue)
Secondary_Endpoints: Muscle strength; plasma mitochondrial biomarkers; body composition
Key_Findings: Urolithin A improved muscle endurance (distance walked in 6 minutes) and hand grip strength in older adults. Improved plasma mitochondrial biomarkers.
Publication_Reference: Singh A et al. Cell Rep Med. 2022;3(11):100824. DOI: 10.1016/j.xcrm.2022.100824

Trial_Title: CLARITY: Urolithin A (Mitopure) ATLAS Phase 2 for Mitochondrial Health
Intervention: Urolithin A (Mitopure) 500 mg or 1000 mg daily vs. placebo for 4 months
Primary_Endpoint: Muscle mitochondrial gene expression (RNA-seq from muscle biopsies); plasma acylcarnitines
Secondary_Endpoints: Muscle strength (hand grip, leg press); endurance (6-minute walk); body composition; plasma biomarkers
Key_Findings: Urolithin A improved mitochondrial biomarkers: reduced plasma acylcarnitines (improved mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation), improved mitochondrial gene expression in muscle. 500 mg dose improved leg muscle strength. Well-tolerated.
Publication_Reference: Liu S et al. JAMA Netw Open. 2022;5(1):e2144279. DOI: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2021.44279; Andreux PA et al. Nat Metab. 2019;1(6):595-603.

Trial_Title: TAZPOWER / MMPOWER-3: Elamipretide for Mitochondrial Myopathy
Intervention: Elamipretide (SS-31) subcutaneous injection
Target_Population: Adults and adolescents with primary mitochondrial myopathy
Primary_Endpoint: 6-minute walk test distance; fatigue scores
Secondary_Endpoints: Exercise tolerance; cardiac function; quality of life; biomarkers of mitochondrial function; safety
Key_Findings: Mixed results across trials. MMPOWER-3 did not meet primary endpoint for 6-minute walk improvement. TAZPOWER showed some benefit in Barth syndrome subgroup. FDA rejected initial NDA; additional data required.
Publication_Reference: Stealth BioTherapeutics press releases and FDA communications.

Trial_Title: Rapamycin for Alzheimer's Disease Phase 1
Intervention: Topical or low-dose systemic rapamycin
Target_Population: Adults aged 55-80 with early Alzheimer's disease
Primary_Endpoint: Safety/tolerability; pharmacokinetics; CSF biomarkers
Secondary_Endpoints: Cognitive assessments; brain MRI; amyloid/tau PET; inflammatory markers
Key_Findings: Preliminary data: rapamycin was well-tolerated at low doses. CSF penetration confirmed. Detailed efficacy data pending.
Publication_Reference: Kaeberlein M and Galvan V. Sci Transl Med. 2019. DOI: 10.1126/scitranslmed.aar4289 (rationale paper)

Trial_Title: EVOKE/EVOKE+: Semaglutide for Early Alzheimer's Disease
Intervention: Oral semaglutide 14 mg daily vs. placebo
Target_Population: Adults aged 55-85 with MCI due to AD or mild AD dementia
Primary_Endpoint: Change in CDR-SB (Clinical Dementia Rating Sum of Boxes) at 104 weeks
Secondary_Endpoints: Cognitive composites; brain atrophy (MRI volumetrics); amyloid/tau PET; daily function; biomarkers
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Largest trial of a GLP-1 agonist in Alzheimer's disease. Based on preclinical evidence of GLP-1 agonist neuroprotection and anti-inflammatory effects.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration. Based on SELECT and GLP-1 neurological evidence.

Trial_Title: Rubedo Life Sciences RLS-1496 for Actinic Keratosis
Intervention: RLS-1496 topical senolytic compound
Primary_Endpoint: Lesion clearance rate; safety/tolerability
Secondary_Endpoints: Histological assessment; senescent cell markers in biopsies; recurrence rate; cosmetic outcomes
Key_Findings: Not yet available. First clinical trial of a targeted topical senolytic for precancerous skin lesions.
Publication_Reference: Company disclosures and press releases.

Trial_Title: Klotho + Follistatin Combination Trial for Aging
Intervention: Recombinant Klotho protein + Follistatin combination
Condition_Indication: Aging biomarkers; muscle and cognitive function
Primary_Endpoint: Safety/tolerability; blood Klotho levels; cognitive function
Secondary_Endpoints: Muscle strength; inflammatory markers; renal function; bone density; epigenetic age
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Novel approach combining longevity factor Klotho with muscle-protective Follistatin.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: D+Q for Mental Disorders Pilot (Senolytic Therapy for Frailty and Psychiatric Comorbidity)
Intervention: Dasatinib 100 mg + Quercetin 1000 mg, 3 consecutive days every 2 weeks for 12 weeks
Condition_Indication: Frailty with psychiatric comorbidity; age-related mental disorders
Target_Population: Frail older adults (Fried Frailty Phenotype 3+ criteria) aged 65-90 with psychiatric comorbidity
Primary_Endpoint: Change in gait speed (m/s) and SASP markers (IL-6, MMP-3, PAI-1)
Secondary_Endpoints: Grip strength; Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB); senescent cell markers in blood (p16INK4a, p21); frailty index; psychiatric symptom measures; patient-reported outcomes
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Testing whether senolytic therapy improves both physical and mental health outcomes in frail older adults.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: PARTICIPAGE: Rapamycin for Aging (AgelessRx)
Intervention: Rapamycin (5-6 mg weekly) vs. placebo; decentralized trial design
Primary_Endpoint: Visceral fat (DEXA); epigenetic age; immune markers
Secondary_Endpoints: Blood biomarkers; self-reported outcomes; frailty measures
Key_Findings: No formal results yet. Novel decentralized trial model for longevity research.
Publication_Reference: Trial registration only.

Trial_Title: Test of Rapamycin in Aging Dogs (TRIAD)
Sponsor: Dog Aging Project / University of Washington; PI: Matt Kaeberlein
Intervention: Low-dose rapamycin (0.1 mg/kg or 0.05 mg/kg, 3x/week) vs. placebo for 3 years
Target_Population: Middle-aged large-breed companion dogs (>40 lbs, aged 7+)
Primary_Endpoint: All-cause mortality (lifespan)
Secondary_Endpoints: Cardiac function (echocardiography); activity levels; owner-reported health; cancer incidence; cognitive function
Key_Findings: Pilot study (Urfer et al. 2017): 10-week rapamycin improved diastolic cardiac function in middle-aged dogs. TRIAD is the largest RCT of a longevity drug in companion animals.
Publication_Reference: Urfer SR et al. GeroScience. 2017;39(2):117-127. DOI: 10.1007/s11357-017-9972-z; Creevy KE et al. Nature. 2022;602:51-57.

Trial_Title: Everolimus for Immune Aging (Mannick Phase 2a)
Intervention: Everolimus 0.5 mg daily, 5 mg weekly, or 20 mg weekly vs. placebo for 6 weeks
Condition_Indication: Immune aging; vaccine response in elderly
Primary_Endpoint: Influenza vaccine antibody response (hemagglutination inhibition titers) at 4 weeks post-vaccination
Secondary_Endpoints: T-cell subsets; PD-1 expression on CD4/CD8 T cells; safety
Key_Findings: Landmark result. Low-dose everolimus (0.5 mg daily or 5 mg weekly) ENHANCED influenza vaccine response by ~20% in elderly. Paradigm-shifting: mTOR inhibitor improved immune function rather than suppressing it.
Publication_Reference: Mannick JB et al. Sci Transl Med. 2014;6(268):268ra179. DOI: 10.1126/scitranslmed.3009892

Trial_Title: PROTECTOR 1: RTB101 for Prevention of Respiratory Tract Infections in Elderly
Intervention: RTB101 10 mg daily (catalytic mTOR inhibitor) vs. placebo for 16 weeks
Primary_Endpoint: Incidence of laboratory-confirmed respiratory tract infections
Secondary_Endpoints: Severity of infections; duration; quality of life; immune markers
Key_Findings: FAILED. RTB101 monotherapy did NOT significantly reduce respiratory tract infections vs. placebo. Phase 2b combination with everolimus had shown 30.6% reduction. Major setback for the field.
Publication_Reference: Mannick JB et al. Lancet Healthy Longev. 2021;2(5):e250-e262. DOI: 10.1016/S2666-7568(21)00062-3

Trial_Title: SmartAge: Spermidine for Cognitive Function
Sponsor: Charite - Universitaetsmedizin Berlin; PI: Agnes Floeel
Intervention: Plant-derived spermidine ~1.2 mg/day from wheat germ extract vs. placebo for 3 months
Target_Population: Older adults aged 60-90 with subjective cognitive decline
Primary_Endpoint: Memory performance (mnemonic similarity task, face-name association)
Secondary_Endpoints: Other cognitive tests; brain MRI (hippocampal volume, connectivity); blood biomarkers
Key_Findings: Spermidine supplementation showed a trend toward improved memory performance, reaching significance in some secondary endpoints. Improved mnemonic discrimination. Effect sizes were modest.

Trial_Title: Nicotinamide Riboside for Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction
Sponsor: University of Colorado; PI: Priya Ramaswamy
Intervention: NR 1000 mg/day (escalated from 500 mg BID) vs. placebo for 12 weeks
Condition_Indication: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)
Primary_Endpoint: Whole blood NAD+ levels; mitochondrial respiration in PBMCs
Secondary_Endpoints: Cardiac function (echocardiography, 6-minute walk); NYHA class; biomarkers (BNP, troponin)
Key_Findings: NR increased PBMC NAD+ metabolites and improved mitochondrial respiration in PBMCs. However, no significant improvement in cardiac function, exercise capacity, or clinical endpoints.
Publication_Reference: Zhou B et al. Circulation. 2020;142(21):1826-1828. DOI: 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.120.050116

Trial_Title: GlyNAC (Glycine + N-Acetylcysteine) Supplementation in Older Adults
Sponsor: Baylor College of Medicine; PI: Rajagopal Sekhar
Intervention: Glycine 100 mg/kg/day + N-Acetylcysteine 100 mg/kg/day vs. placebo for 16-24 weeks
Primary_Endpoint: Glutathione (GSH) levels; oxidative stress markers (TBARS, F2-isoprostanes); mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation
Secondary_Endpoints: Gait speed; grip strength; exercise capacity; cognitive tests; body composition; genomic damage markers; insulin resistance
Key_Findings: Remarkably broad improvements: corrected glutathione deficiency, reduced oxidative stress, improved mitochondrial function, reduced inflammation, improved insulin resistance, improved gait speed, grip strength, cognition, and exercise capacity. Effects reversed after stopping.
Publication_Reference: Kumar P et al. J Gerontol A. 2021;76(1):75-83. DOI: 10.1093/gerona/glaa243; Kumar P et al. Clin Transl Med. 2021;11(3):e372.

Trial_Title: SELECT: Semaglutide Effects on Cardiovascular Outcomes in Overweight/Obesity
Intervention: Semaglutide 2.4 mg subcutaneous weekly vs. placebo
Condition_Indication: Cardiovascular outcomes in overweight/obesity without diabetes
Target_Population: Adults aged 45+ with overweight/obesity and established cardiovascular disease (no diabetes)
Primary_Endpoint: MACE-3 (cardiovascular death, non-fatal MI, non-fatal stroke)
Secondary_Endpoints: All-cause mortality; heart failure events; renal outcomes; individual MACE components
Key_Findings: Major positive result. Semaglutide reduced MACE by 20% (HR 0.80, 95% CI 0.72-0.90, p<0.001). Reduced all-cause death by 19%. First GLP-1 RA to show cardiovascular benefit in non-diabetic population. Weight loss ~9.4%.
Publication_Reference: Lincoff AM et al. N Engl J Med. 2023;389(24):2221-2232. DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa2307563

Trial_Title: STEP-HFpEF: Semaglutide in HFpEF with Obesity
Intervention: Semaglutide 2.4 mg subcutaneous weekly vs. placebo for 52 weeks
Condition_Indication: Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF) with obesity
Primary_Endpoint: Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ) clinical summary score; body weight
Secondary_Endpoints: 6-minute walk distance; CRP; NT-proBNP; heart failure events
Key_Findings: Semaglutide significantly improved KCCQ scores (+7.8 points vs placebo), body weight (-13.3% vs -2.6%), 6-minute walk distance (+21.5 m vs +1.2 m), and CRP reduction. First drug to substantially improve symptoms and function in HFpEF with obesity.
Publication_Reference: Kosiborod MN et al. N Engl J Med. 2023;389(12):1069-1084. DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa2304430

Trial_Title: MIB-626 (Crystalline NMN) Phase 2 Trial
Intervention: MIB-626 (crystalline beta-NMN) 1000 mg once or twice daily vs. placebo
Primary_Endpoint: Blood and tissue NAD+ levels; metabolic parameters
Secondary_Endpoints: Insulin sensitivity; body composition; safety/tolerability; physical function
Key_Findings: Phase 1 data: MIB-626 1000 mg/day safely increased blood NAD+ levels by ~2-fold in overweight adults. Dose-proportional pharmacokinetics. Well-tolerated.
Publication_Reference: Pencina KM et al. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2023;108(9):e748-e756.

Trial_Title: AFFIRM-KNEE: Fisetin for Osteoarthritis of the Knee
Intervention: Fisetin 20 mg/kg/day for 2 consecutive days
Primary_Endpoint: Adverse events and feasibility
Secondary_Endpoints: Joint function (WOMAC); pain (VAS); senescence markers in synovial fluid; inflammatory markers
Key_Findings: Safety data: well-tolerated; no serious adverse events. Efficacy data pending full publication.
Publication_Reference: Not yet published in peer-reviewed journal as of early 2025.

Trial_Title: D+Q for Bone Health / Osteoporosis (Mayo)
Intervention: Dasatinib 100 mg + Quercetin 1250 mg, 3 days per month for 3-6 months
Condition_Indication: Age-related bone loss; low bone density
Target_Population: Postmenopausal women aged 60-85 with low bone density (T-score -1.0 to -2.5)
Primary_Endpoint: Bone resorption markers (CTX, P1NP); osteocyte senescence markers in bone biopsies
Secondary_Endpoints: Bone mineral density (DXA); SASP factors; physical function
Key_Findings: Not yet available. Based on preclinical data (Farr et al. 2017) showing D+Q reduced bone loss in aged mice.
Publication_Reference: Farr JN et al. Nat Med. 2017;23(9):1072-1079. (preclinical basis)
